TEXT: The applicant , a NORP citizen born in DATE , is resident in GPE .
A. Particular facts of the case

In DATE , the applicant was practising as a solicitor in GPE , GPE . In DATE , he met PERSON at a ORG . PERSON proposed that he and the applicant go into business together at an office in GPE Street , GPE , GPE . PERSON was to provide the applicant with legal clerking services in return for receiving PERCENT of all monies received . This arrangement was started DATE .
Unbeknown to the applicant , PERSON recently had been released from prison following DATE sentence for conspiring to obtain property by deception and fraudulent trading .

In DATE , this fact was intimated to the applicant by a fellow solicitor . The applicant states that before he had an opportunity to confront PERSON , another solicitor bought the practice from him for the sum of £ MONEY . The applicant did not inform the purchaser of PERSON 's background .

Whilst working with the applicant , PERSON had forged the applicant 's signature on cheques causing losses of MONEY . In the subsequent arrangement , losses to members of the public amounted to MONEY .
After he had sold the practice , the police had occasion to question the applicant about his dealings with PERSON , and took a statement from him . No criminal prosecution ever occurred .

Following this , there was a civil action in ORG against PERSON and the solicitor to whom the applicant sold the business . In the course of this trial , the applicant gave evidence on oath about his involvement with PERSON .
Following this trial , in DATE ORG ( ORG ) wrote to the applicant . Correspondence passed between them .
On DATE , proceedings were issued against the applicant for professional misconduct . He eventually faced CARDINAL allegations :

CARDINAL . that he had been guilty of conduct unbefitting a solicitor in that he established and operated a solicitor 's practice principally managed by an unqualified clerk in circumstances which were improper having regard to the extent of his knowledge of the said clerk and the supervision provided ;

ORG that he had been guilty of conduct unbefitting a solicitor in that , being in possession of information indicating that the said clerk was dishonest , having been convicted of serious offences of dishonesty and sentenced to a term of imprisonment , he failed to take any reasonable or sufficient steps to protect the profession or the public ; and

CARDINAL . that he had been guilty of conduct unbefitting a solicitor and/or failed to comply with Rule CARDINAL of the Solicitors Practice Rules DATE and DATE ( fee sharing ) in that he established and operated a solicitor 's practice on the basis that the said unqualified clerk would be entitled to receive CARDINAL of the gross fees thereof to cover , inter alia , office overheads for which the said clerk was to be responsible .

The hearing of ORG ( SCT ) took place on DATE . The applicant represented himself . At the conclusion of the hearing the charges were found to be proved against him and he was fined a total of £ MONEY . In their written findings of CARDINAL DATE the ORG divided the sum between the CARDINAL charges .

On DATE , the applicant appealed to ORG of ORG . Correspondence began between himself and the court with regard to the length of time required for the hearing . The applicant 's estimation was for DATE hearing . The court allotted TIME .
The hearing was on DATE and lasted for TIME . The applicant had provided a skeleton argument and a lengthy list of authorities beforehand .

The issues raised on appeal were the same as those raised before the ORG . The applicant did not question the facts as found by the ORG , but claimed that all the evidence against him was technically inadmissible and therefore there was no case against him . The evidence consisted of the statement made to the police , the evidence given by the applicant in the civil trial and correspondence between the applicant and the ORG .

In ORG judgment of DATE , rejecting the applicant 's appeal and holding him liable in costs , the Lord Chief Justice held that the ORG had a discretion not to apply the strict rules of evidence . He observed that the applicant had also consented to the police evidence going before the FAC . Insofar as the applicant argued that the evidence given on oath in the civil proceedings should not have been used against him as it infringed his right to self - incrimination , Lord PERSON held that :

" [ the applicant ] is not being sued or prosecuted for any statement that he made in the witness box . He is the subject of ORG proceedings not as a result of what he said in the witness box but of what he did [ in relation to PERSON ] " .
On DATE , the applicant applied for leave to appeal to ORG . There was a brief hearing on DATE after which that application was rejected . Costs were awarded against him .
PERSON Relevant domestic law

Proceedings against solicitors are governed by LAW , as amended , and give the GPE the power to fine solicitors , suspend them from practice or to strike them off the ORG roll . The limits of the fines may be increased in line with inflation by secondary legislation . In DATE , the amount was limited to £ MONEY . In DATE , this was increased to £ MONEY . On DATE , the sum was increased to £ MONEY in respect of each offence proved against the solicitor . For the purposes of the LAW , the relevant date is that of the hearing .

Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the Solicitors Act DATE states that the fine is to be considered as if it was made by a ORG Judge . As with any civil debt , if the amount remains unpaid , the defaulter is liable to imprisonment on default for a period of DATE ( section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) Debtors Act DATE ) . In the case of solicitors , this is also a breach of their position as an officer of the court under which they can be committed to prison under the discretionary ground in section CARDINAL of LAW .
